stream_context.summary: Kaze iterates on an “Arts & Crafts / cardboard” sub-area: modular floating platforms with color variations, falling triggers, and planned saw hazards, while wrestling with scaling/UV issues and engine “overflow/underflow” problems. He also discusses emulator-specific rendering ideas (and rejects adding lots of options), speedrun-design philosophy (BLJs, invisible walls), demo plans (including a hidden Delfino Plaza), and his pragmatic stance on YouTube as income rather than passion.
stream_context.significance_reason: Contains multiple documentary-relevant threads: a concrete level concept with hazards and modular placement, a real technical blocker (scaling vs UVs / exporter mismatch), explicit speedrun philosophy guiding design choices, a specific demo plan tease (hidden Delfino Plaza), and unusually candid business motivation about YouTube vs game dev.

findings.summary: Kaze outlines the core gameplay concept for the cardboard sub-area: modular floating platforms arranged into a fast-paced “race” where platforms fall after you approach and saw hazards activate when you get close, pushing players to keep moving.

The sub-area’s theme is intentionally “crude materials” (cardboard, painted surfaces). Kaze imagines an abyss, lava below, and cardboard pieces visually falling into lava as the player platforms across.

A key technical friction point is scaling geometry while keeping textures/UVs correct: scaling platforms didn’t affect UVs the way he needs, causing stretching. He considers dynamically generating vertices or otherwise making UV scaling follow model scaling, but notes it would require extra custom programming.

He hits repeated “overflow/underflow” style issues while iterating on this area (and tries fixes like adjusting platform parameters and spacing). He ultimately considers splitting large scaled platforms into multiple smaller ones to reduce distortion and side effects.

Kaze observes a mismatch between how transforms/scales appear in Blender versus how they end up in-game (Mario 64), leading him to scrap and rebuild the problematic platforms rather than chase the discrepancy indefinitely.

Movement changes/quirks in his engine produce new tech: he notices a long-jump interaction that can force a front flip, tied to his earlier change where braking + holding forward yields a forward flip (originally done to make side flips more consistent).

He argues against excessive toggles/settings, framing “less options is better,” and mocks the idea of adding options for tiny aesthetic complaints—preferring clear defaults even if some emulator users dislike visuals.

Kaze states a speedrun philosophy: BLJs and skips are only exciting in moderation; if speedruns rely on constant exploits and the game becomes unrecognizable compared to casual play, the speedrun becomes less fun to watch/play.
He confirms the “Course 1 demo is still planned” and floats adding a hidden unlockable Delfino Plaza area (Super Mario Sunshine) running on N64 as an extra demo secret.

He’s candid that YouTube videos are primarily income-driven for him right now: he’s testing what content performs, felt his BLJ-focused video underperformed, and frames his professional priorities as finishing the game and earning money.

zeina.summary: Kaze casually references their daily routine: he often starts working before breakfast while Zeina takes longer to get up, then they eat once she’s up.

findings.summary: Kaze jokingly blames certain recurring errors on Sauraen and implies some low-level rendering/engine warnings have become background noise during development.

key_stories.title: Building the Arts & Crafts sub-area as a modular falling-platform race
key_stories.summary: Kaze defines the cardboard sub-area as a momentum-focused platforming sequence built from reusable platform pieces. The identity hinges on platforms that fall when approached and hazards (saws) that activate based on proximity, creating pressure to keep moving.
key_stories.challenge: Translate a modular platform concept into something that looks coherent (painted/cardboard) while remaining readable, fun, and technically stable.
key_stories.process: He blockouts platform layouts with two core platform designs, experiments with random colors, tunes spacing/difficulty, and plans hazard placement (saws between platforms). He iterates on the theme (abyss/lava/cardboard) while trying to get acceptable floor visuals.
key_stories.outcome: The core route begins to feel fun in his own playtests, but he flags remaining work: floor texture solution, saw implementation/placement, and tuning difficulty for non-expert players.

key_stories.title: Scaling vs UVs vs Blender export: rebuilding platforms instead of chasing ghosts
key_stories.summary: While trying to add variety via scaled platforms, Kaze runs into texture stretching and apparent differences between Blender’s transforms and what Mario 64 ends up using. The debugging cost pushes him toward a pragmatic rebuild approach.
key_stories.challenge: Scaled platforms look wrong (UVs don’t scale as desired), and some platforms appear to have inexplicable offsets/incorrect scale once in-engine, suggesting pipeline or transform-application mismatch.
key_stories.process: He considers more advanced solutions (dynamic vertex generation / UV scaling tied to geometry), explores splitting geometry into smaller pieces to reduce scaling dependence, and repeatedly checks parameters/scale values. After failing to reconcile the mismatch quickly, he decides to remake the platforms cleanly.
key_stories.outcome: He abandons the broken instances and opts for rebuilding the platform assets/layout in a way that avoids the transform/UV pitfalls, accepting that a clean reset is faster than deep pipeline forensics in the moment.

open_questions.topic: Hidden Delfino Plaza in the Course 1 demo
open_questions.context: Kaze says Course 1’s demo is still planned and suggests including Delfino Plaza as a hidden unlockable secret in the demo.
questions: What’s the creative reason to include Delfino Plaza specifically—nostalgia, a technical flex, a tone-setter, or a reward for exploration?
How far would you take it in the demo: a visual hub, a playable sandbox, or a teaser with one interaction/star?
What technical compromises were required to make a Sunshine-scale location feel right on N64 (memory, geometry density, textures, NPCs/objects), and what did you cut first?

open_questions.topic: Speedrun philosophy shaping level and exploit design
open_questions.context: He argues that too many BLJs/major skips make speedruns less fun if the run becomes unrecognizable from casual play; he also estimates eventual any% and 100% times.
questions: Where do you draw the line between ‘expressive movement’ and ‘run-destroying exploit’—and how do you decide what to patch, limit, or embrace?
Are there specific places you’re intentionally designing to allow one or two exciting skips, while preventing the run from turning into constant BLJ/clip spam?
How are you planning to test this—will you bring in speedrunners early, or wait until levels are locked?

open_questions.topic: Resolving scaled-platform visuals (UV behavior) without exploding workload
open_questions.context: Kaze struggles with UV stretching when scaling platforms and considers more advanced engine-side fixes (dynamic vertices/UV scaling) versus changing level construction (more smaller pieces).
questions: What’s the long-term plan: invest in a robust engine-side solution so artists/designers can scale freely, or constrain the art pipeline to avoid scaling altogether?
If you do implement dynamic vertex/UV scaling, what’s the risk to performance on real hardware, and how would you validate it doesn’t introduce new rendering edge cases?
How often do these Blender→in-game transform mismatches happen across the project, and did they change how you structure assets and exports going forward?
